name: RT
comment info: This block format which is weighted by population is VERY important because it avoids the deception conveyed with the simplistic geographically accurate but highly inaccurate typical presidential electoral map which gives rural areas voting Repub / Red much more visibility than they deserve.

name: Ellie
comment info: The first thing I noticed were the flipped states; I noticed that Biden flipped AZ, PA, GA, MI, WI, and a district in NE. The second thing I noticed was the main difference between the 2  maps; the 1st map breaks the states down by the number of electoral votes while the 2nd map shows states, their geographical borders, and how the state voted as a whole. The setup of the 2nd map is a bit misleading. For example, in Nebraska, Trump won the state, but Biden won the 2nd congressional district and 1 out of 5 of Nebraska's electoral college votes. An individual wouldn't be able to gather that information from the second map and would have a false sense of complete unity within each state. Whereas the 1st map highlights the disunity and conflicting views within states. I wonder which map is more commonly published and why. This has a large impact on me personally; I am a senior in high school, so the stance of the party in the White House holds on student loans will have a large impact on my financial situation throughout college and the beginning of my adult life. My community will also feel the impacts of this decision -- both beneficial and harmful. I live in a rural community that has a lack of access to adequate healthcare and the new administration's policy aims to improve that, but my community is also comprised of a majority of farmers, who were greatly dependant upon the subsidies under the Trump administration. Catchy Headline: Is America Red, Blue, or Purple?

name: Meg Elizabeth
comment info: From the map of the Electoral College's results, I noticed that Biden flipped in AZ, PA, GA, MI, WI, and one district in NE and flat outwon in VT, NH, MA, NY, NJ, CT, RI, DE, MD, VA, DC, IL, MN, CO, NM, CA, OR, WA, HI, NV, and 3 districts in ME. Trump flat out won ID, MT, ND, SD, WY, UT, IA, KS, AK, OK, TX, MO, AR, LA, AL, MS, FL, NC, SC, WV, TN, KY, IN, OH, four districts from NE and district from ME, flipping in none of the districts. From the state winner map, I noticed that Biden flipped in PA, MI, WI, AZ, GA, and NE 2; he won CA, NV, OR, WA, NM, CO, MN, IL, NY, VA, MD, DE, HI, NJ, CT, RI, MA, VT, NH, and ME 1. Trump flipped in none of the states, but won MT, WY, ID, UT, AK, ND, SD, NE 1 and 3, KS, OK, TX, IA, MO, AR, LA, MS, AL, TN, KY, FL, NC, SC, WV, IN, and OH. I wonder why the northeast, some of the midwest, and west coast voted for Biden and the plains, some of the mid-west, and the south voted Republican? These results impacted my community by raising the chances of a member of the LGBTQ+ community to be hate-crimed and raised the taxes. These maps show the results of the 2020 Presidential Election in the state winner votes and electoral college votes. A catchy headline I would give these maps would be "Donald Trump succeeded from the White House.

name: Olivia
comment info:
#1) When looking at the map I first noticed that the electoral votes are clearly recorded at the top of both maps. At first glance, it would appear that there is a higher number of red states than blue states. However, through further analysis and outside research, one can see that the areas that are predominantly red tend to be states comprised primarily of rural, white communities with smaller populations, and fewer electoral votes ( since the number of votes per state is proportional to each state's population). While the blue states are primarily comprised of larger diverse communities with more electoral votes. 

#2) I wonder why the first map is not publicized as widely as the second map. The first map allows for a simplified explanation of the electoral votes, which, in turn, allows for greater accessibility to a wide range of people across the country. 

#3) This impacts everyone in my community, and around the world because of the power that the president of the United States holds—the power to make potentially life-altering decisions for millions of people. These maps will help to educate Americans on the political system that holds millions of lives in its grasp. 

#4) Headline: “Confused how electoral votes work? Check out this simplified map.”

name: Maya
comment info: I notice that both maps display the 2020 election results, but the first map does so more accurately. In the first map, each state is depicted by the number of electoral votes, one block representing one vote. The second map shows the states’ actual sizes which are colored to represent whoever won that state. In the second map, it falsely suggests that bigger states carry more weight in the election which is why Trump appears to be leading. By completely ignoring the electoral vote, it does not consider the weight each states’ votes have accounting for their population, as the first map does. Oklahoma is much larger than Connecticut on the second map when in reality, they have the same amount of electoral votes. I wonder why the second map is what we most commonly see during elections? It can be very misleading as it does not account for smaller states with higher populations, which in this case are the majority of what Biden won. I also wonder why Nebraska and Maine have split electoral votes? I’m curious what the advantage is of doing this is instead of using winner takes all like every other state. This has an impact on my community and me because New Hampshire is a geographically small state. The first map reveals that our votes may be weighted more than we realize, every vote does count. NH has only one less electoral vote than Colorado, which appears much larger on the second map. My headline is: “Are the Maps We Usually See as Accurate as We’ve Been Led To Believe?"

name: Collin

We don't have to turn all the way to the craziness that is the first map, but it would be a lot clearer if there was some indication of how many votes each state gives to their candidate. This affect my community because I think the 2nd map can be misleading. Some of people have been insinuating that the voting is rigged, or that the government cheated in Biden's favor. Most people have these opinions because of voter fraud, but it's likely that some see the 2nd map and think that Trump clearly won, so were shocked to see that Biden ended up winning.

replies.comment info: @Collin I totally agree. The amount of people who don’t understand how elections work is incredibly large. If people understood how it actually works, there wouldn’t be so much backlash and toxicity, and we could possibly create a peaceful transition of power.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Jamie The ballots that "poured in for Biden" were not mysterious in any way, in fact, they were expected. While Donald Trump denounced mail-in voting and told his supporters to vote in person, Joe Biden and other Democrats supported mail-in voting as a way of stopping the spread of covid and being safer. Because mail-in votes take slightly longer to travel to polling places, the heavily democratic mail-in votes from Philadelphia and Allegheny came in overwhelmingly for Biden, as they were mail-in, which Trump did not support and from already-Democratic areas. This is what caused Joe Biden to win, and it was actually expected. There is nothing mysterious here, buddy

replies.name: H
replies.comment info: @Alex Having the top map presented the way it is can show visually why Biden won the election. States are to scale based on how many electoral votes they have (one box for each electoral vote). This means that since Biden won the election, there are many more blue boxes (states) than red boxes. While the number of electoral votes could have been put on a geographically correct map of the U.S., having the data presented the way it is in the top map helps us see visually why Biden won. If electoral votes were put on the bottom map, it would still look like Trump should have won the election by quickly looking at it because more areas would be red. Displaying data is all about how our eyes will visually conceive the data, as this creates a bias before we begin to analyze the data.

name: Luisa
comment info:
What do you notice?

I notice that the first map is organized by electoral votes, providing a proportional representation of electorate distribution corresponding to the actual results of the election, showing a clear victory for Biden, whereas the second map is simply shaded in by land area, making the country appear disproportionately red. Additionally, I noticed that 5 states appear to have learned from their mistakes in 2016 and flipped. I noticed as well that the 10 most educated states voted for Biden, while the 7 least educated states voted for Trump.

What do you wonder?

I wonder if the electoral college is a fair system, or if it’s outdated due to drastic differences in circumstance from the 1700s to today. The system was created to prevent a tyrannical majority from dominating rural areas, however it seems to be that a lot of bigots are exploiting this system and targeting marginalized communities throughout the country against the wishes of a majority of Americans as can be seen by the 2016 popular vote.

What impact does this have on you and your community?

As a small state, New Hampshire is given disproportionate representation when it comes to electorate votes, and the layout shows how a NH vote has more than twice the value of a vote in CA.

What’s going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the maps’ main idea.

“Some mistakes are made, that’s alright, that's ok: 5 states learn from their mistakes and turn blue, securing Biden’s victory.”

name: Tovi
comment info:
What do you notice: I noticed in the states which adopted a congressional district model of electoral voting, one elector voted against the consensus of the rest of the state electors' votes. In both Maine and Nebraska, it was their second district, but for different parties. Maine's 2nd district contains a majority of their rural land (accounting for their red vote) whilst Nebraska's second district contains Omaha, the largest city in the state (accounting for the blue vote).

What do you wonder: Is the electoral system really fair in its current state? Is it fair at all? Does it make sense that land should have a higher say in the leadership of the nation? In a nation as large and with needs as separate as ours, does it make sense to perpetuate the system which sees the election of one national figurehead? A state could have a near perfectly split popular vote yet those few votes could decide the entire say of that given state. 

What impact does this have on you and your community: This map really hammers home the importance of voting and making our voices be heard. As a community, we HAVE to make our opinions known to the national stage and the most surefire way to do so is to vote. 

What’s going on in this graph: This graph shows the shifting opinions of the nation since the last election and displays the various wants and needs of the people who voted in their respective regions. A potential headline could be: "Separate Needs, Seperate Worlds: A nation fragmented".

name: Tyson
comment info: I notice that the two different maps show two different things. The top one, which I believe is a better map, shows the electoral votes that each state has, as well as who had more votes in that state, whereas the bottom map only shows who had more votes in each state, with no depiction of how many electoral votes each state has. I wonder why most maps that I see don't show the electoral votes, but only the states, like the bottom map. I feel that the top map is a much better depiction of who is currently winning the election. These maps impact me and my community because I feel like a lot of times, kids that are my age can't really fathom what the electoral college is, so the top map really gives people my age a good idea of what the electoral college is and how it works. For instance, when I was talking to one of my friends about the election, they said that if there wasn't a bar on the top of the map showing who was winning, they would think that the Republican was winning, although, in reality, it's the Democrat. A heading for the top map could be "Election Results by Electoral Vote", and a heading for the bottom map could be "Election Results by States' Popular Vote". In conclusion, I feel that the top map gives people a better idea of not only how the electoral college works, but who is truly winning the election, and why, even though the Republican had more states' popular vote, the Democrat actually was winning.

replies.comment info: @bady Great answer! You ask how there are more red states, but the Democratic candidate is winning. This is because the blue states have more electoral votes and their  vote has a larger say in the total vote. For example, even though California is one state, it has 55 electoral votes. Contrastingly, Alaska only has 3. This is because California has a much larger population than Alaska. The states that Biden won have larger populations and therefore more electoral votes. That is why Biden won with less states than Trump.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  
Today’s maps show the 2020 Presidential election results in two different ways.  Compare the maps.  How are they similar?  How are they different?  Which map does a better job of visualizing the outcome of the election?  
Share your noticings and wonderings with others.  Together, you will come up with a better understanding of the story that these graphs tell.
From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you?”

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in the map. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included this map and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Keep noticing and wondering.  The next release will be by Friday, Dec. 4 with moderation on Wednesday, Dec. 9.  The graph is about how the United States compares to countries worldwide.

name: Bridget R
comment info:
The second map is much more misleading than the second map because it would appear that the majority of the states are red and therefore Trump should have won. This however is incorrect and why the first map more accurately displays the 2020 election. The first map has each block represent one electoral vote, and shows how the votes were distributed in the 2020 election. It incorporates not only which states voted for which candidate but also the number of electoral votes for each state. 

I wonder why Maine and Nebraska each have split electoral votes. I also wonder why the second map is so much more common when it is quite misleading. I think that it would be smarter to use the first map more often because it seems to give a better perspective on who won the election. There might be a reason why the second map is more common, so I wonder what that reason is.


The impact that this has on my community is that it allows me to visualize how much of an impact which candidate New Hampshire elects has on the election in proportion to other states. It shows me how many electoral votes we have and who those electoral votes went to. This was a huge election so it is very important to know what impact your state had on it. 

The first map shows each state with the electoral college votes by winner, while the second map just shows each state’s winner. A headline for the graphs would be “The 2020 Election: Electoral Votes vs. Land Mass”.

A possible reason that Maine and Nebraska have some democratic and some republican electoral college votes is that the people within the electoral college had diversity in the way that they voted (whether by personal choice or based on the states voting results).

name: Hannah
comment info: The first thing I notice from these maps is how the change in how the data is displayed makes a big difference in interpreting the data. In the top map, the states are represented based on their electoral votes, making it appear that Biden received more votes, which is accurate. In the bottom map, states are colored by which candidate won them overall, making it appear as if Trump won more of the country. This is misleading because the areas that Trump won are less populated than where Biden won, leading to Biden's win. I wonder how people working in the polling industry use the displaying of data to guide the population to one belief or another. I find it interesting but worrying that people who make political maps can use the human eye to make people believe something that isn’t true. This is the impact that these maps have on my community: we all see things every day that are misleading, but we often believe these things anyway. I hope that non-misleading forms of visual data will become more widely used so that data presented to the public does not come with forms of bias. In terms of what is going on in each map, they both represent two very different things. For the top map, I would title this one “Which Candidate Won the Majority of Electoral Votes?." I would title the bottom map “The 2020 Presidential Candidate That Won Each State,” as this map does not break the states down into a respective size based on the number of electoral votes.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: @Hunter Turner   The reason why people vote even if it just comes down to the electoral college is because who people vote for determines who the electoral college votes go to: in this case either Trump or Biden. Whoever wins with the most votes from citizens in your state receives the electoral college votes.

To answer your questions...

Red and Blue mean the main two political parties

replies.comment info: @Alexis Your "I wonder" statement is really interesting. Hi, @Susan Sullivan students FL and SBS--

The top map is called a tile map or even a Lego map.  How many tiles are in each state?  How do the number of tiles relate to the Electoral College?  Which states have the most tiles?  The least number of tiles?
